author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there were three little kittens, and their names were Mittens, Tom Kitten, and Moppet.

author: Potter
text: They had dear little fur coats of their own; and they tumbled about the doorstep and played in the dust.

author: Potter
text: But one day their mother--Mrs.

author: Potter
text: Tabitha Twitchit--expected friends to tea; so she fetched the kittens indoors, to wash and dress them, before the fine company arrived.

author: Potter
text: First she scrubbed their faces (this one is Moppet).

author: Potter
text: Then she brushed their fur (this one is Mittens).

author: Potter
text: Then she combed their tails and whiskers (this is Tom Kitten).

author: Potter
text: Tom was very naughty, and he scratched.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tabitha dressed Moppet and Mittens in clean pinafores and tuckers; and then she took all sorts of elegant uncomfortable clothes out of a chest of drawers, in order to dress up her son Thomas.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten was very fat, and he had grown; several buttons burst off.

author: Potter
text: His mother sewed them on again.

author: Potter
text: When the three kittens were ready, Mrs. Tabitha unwisely turned them out into the garden, to be out of the way while she made hot buttered toast.

author: Potter
text: "Now keep your frocks clean, children!

author: Potter
text: You must walk on your hind legs.

author: Potter
text: Keep away from the dirty ash- pit, and from Sally Henny Penny, and from the pigsty and the Puddle- ducks."

author: Potter
text: Moppet and Mittens walked down the garden path unsteadily.

author: Potter
text: Presently they trod upon their pinafores and fell on their noses.

author: Potter
text: When they stood up there were several green smears!

author: Potter
text: "Let us climb up the rockery and sit on the garden wall," said Moppet.

author: Potter
text: They turned their pinafores back to front and went up with a skip and a jump; Moppet's white tucker fell down into the road.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten was quite unable to jump when walking upon his hind legs in trousers.

author: Potter
text: He came up the rockery by degrees, breaking the ferns and shedding buttons right and left.

author: Potter
text: He was all in pieces when he reached the top of the wall.

author: Potter
text: Moppet and Mittens tried to pull him together; his hat fell off, and the rest of his buttons burst.

author: Potter
text: While they were in difficulties, there was a pit pat, paddle pat! and the three Puddle-ducks came along the hard high road, marching one behind the other and doing the goose step-- pit pat, paddle pat! pit pat, waddle pat!

author: Potter
text: They stopped and stood in a row and stared up at the kittens.

author: Potter
text: They had very small eyes and looked surprised.

author: Potter
text: Then the two duck-birds, Rebeccah and Jemima Puddle-duck, picked up the hat and tucker and put them on.

author: Potter
text: Mittens laughed so that she fell off the wall.

author: Potter
text: Moppet and Tom descended after her; the pinafores and all the rest of Tom's clothes came off on the way down.

author: Potter
text: "Come!

author: Potter
text: Mr. Drake Puddle-duck," said Moppet.

author: Potter
text: "Come and help us to dress him!

author: Potter
text: Come and button up Tom!"

author: Potter
text: Mr. Drake Puddle-duck advanced in a slow sideways manner and picked up the various articles.

author: Potter
text: But he put them on HIMSELF!

author: Potter
text: They fitted him even worse than Tom Kitten.

author: Potter
text: "It's a very fine morning!" said Mr. Drake Puddle-duck.

author: Potter
text: And he and Jemima and Rebeccah Puddle-duck set off up the road, keeping step--pit pat, paddle pat! pit pat, waddle pat!

author: Potter
text: Then Tabitha Twitchit came down the garden and found her kittens on the wall with no clothes on.

author: Potter
text: She pulled them off the wall, smacked them, and took them back to the house.

author: Potter
text: "My friends will arrive in a minute, and you are not fit to be seen; I am affronted," said Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit.

author: Potter
text: She sent them upstairs; and I am sorry to say she told her friends that they were in bed with the measles-- which was not true.

author: Potter
text: Quite the contrary; they were not in bed: NOT in the least.

author: Potter
text: Somehow there were very extra-- ordinary noises overhead, which disturbed the dignity and repose of the tea party.

author: Potter
text: And I think that some day I shall have to make another, larger book, to tell you more about Tom Kitten!

author: Potter
text: As for the Puddle-ducks--they went into a pond.

author: Potter
text: The clothes all came off directly, because there were no buttons.

author: Potter
text: And Mr. Drake Puddle-duck, and Jemima and Rebeccah, have been looking for them ever since.
